name: Lisianthius_spruceanus
publication: Hooker's J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc.
reference: Hooker's J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc. 6: 202. 1854

name: Lisianthius_uliginosus
typeLocations: lectotype G;isotype F;isotype GH;isotype NY;isotype US

name: Symphyllophyton_aequalifolium
collectorTeam: C. Snak, A.R. Barbosa & C. Silva
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.521.3.2 Name from the Latin 'æqualis', equal, similar, uniform and 'folium', leaf, referring to the leaves which are similar in size and shape from the base to the apex of the stem.
locality: Sucupira do Riachão, BR 230 km 55, Barão de Grajaú sentido S. João dos Patos, 340 m

name: Symphyllophyton_gradatum
collectorTeam: E.R. Santos, R. Haidar & A.C. Pereira.
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.521.3.2 Name from the Latin 'gradus', meaning step or degree, referring to the leaf sizes and shapes which change gradually from the base to the apex.
locality: Rio Sono, Fazenda Capanga; cerrado stricto sensu em solo arenoso, 220 m

name: Symphyllophyton_horologium
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.521.3.2 The specific epithet refers to the arrangement of the 12 orange triangles on the corolla mouth, resembling a clock; additionally, it makes allusion to the time ticking away the prospects for this rare species to survive, while soybean plantations rapidly encroach upon its native habitat, the Cerrado.
locality: Município de Mambaí, Morro do Pequi, 750 m

name: Symphyllophyton_strictifolium
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.521.3.2 Etymology: the specific epithet is derived from the Latin words 'strictus', narrow, and 'folius', related to the leaves, referring to the characteristic narrow leaves of this new species.
locality: Município de Palmas, Morro do Limpão, a leste da cidade de Palmas
